In 2021, a documentary revealed the racism of flemish football fans.<ref name="be2">{{cite news |title= "Sale nègre", "macaque" : la face dévoilée du racisme dans les clubs de foot flamands |url= https://www.rtbf.be/article/sale-negre-macaque-la-face-devoilee-du-racisme-dans-les-clubs-de-foot-flamands-10755349 |publisher=[[RTBF]] |date=5 May 2021}}</ref> [[Romelu Lukaku]] declared having faced racial insults as young as 11 years-old in his first club in Flanders, according to him the insults came from the parents of adverse players, but only when he played against other flemish teams.<ref name="be2"/> The extreme right in the flemish region is rallying football fans together in racist acts, even across fans from historically adverse teams.<ref name="be2"/>
==Bulgaria== On 9 October 1992, the Bulgarian president signed the Council of Europe [[Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities]], signaling a new commitment to uphold minority rights.<ref>{{cite news |title= Human Rights Watch World Report 1998 – 1 January |url= http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/3ae6a8a510.html |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |date=1 January 1998}}</ref>
In 2011 the parliamentary party [[Attack (political party)|Ataka]], identifying itself as nationalist, attacked the mosque in the center of Sofia during the Friday prayer. In 2013 one of the leaders of another nationalist party, [[IMRO – Bulgarian National Movement|VMRO]], Angel Djambasky was put under investigation for calling the people to arm themselves against the immigrants.
At least 6 racist crimes are perpetrated between 3 and 13 November of every year. 112 intellectuals signed a petition to the attorney general not to register the party Ataka, which was rejected by the attorney general.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnevnik.bg/bulgaria/2011/05/20/1093480_ataka_sreshtu_mjusjulmanite_v_djamiiata_na_sofiia_video/|title=България - "Атака" срещу мюсюлманите в джамията на София (видео) |work=dnevnik.bg|date=20 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://paper.standartnews.com/bg/article.php?d=2013-11-05&article=471190|title= Стандарт|work=standartnews.com}}</ref><ref>[http://www.bghelsinki.org/media/uploads/documents/external/2013-11-13_signal_na_112_grazhdani_sreshtu_neo-nazi_partia.pdf ОТКРИТ СИГНАЛ] (in Bulgarian) Retrieved 6 February 2023</ref>
In October 2019, Bulgarian supporters shouted racist abuse towards Black English footballers during a match.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/10/15/football/bulgaria-england-racism-uefa-gbr-spt-intl/index.html | title=All eyes on UEFA after football's night of shame | first=Aimee | last=Lewis | publisher=CNN | date=17 October 2019 | access-date=30 April 2021 }}</ref>
==Cyprus== The National Popular Front, or National People's Front (Greek: Εθνικό Λαϊκό Μέτωπο (ΕΛΑΜ), Ethniko Laiko Metopo [[ELAM (Cyprus)]]), is a far-right movement (and later, political party) founded in 2008 in the Republic of Cyprus.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |first=James |last=Mackay |date=2012-03-13 |title=Cyprus racism in the spotlight |url=http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/mar/13/cyprus-political-racism-doros-polycarpou |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.today/20220707031606/https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/mar/13/cyprus-political-racism-doros-polycarpou%23comments |archive-date=2022-07-07 |website=[[The Guardian]] |language=en}}</ref> The party has been the subject of controversy in the Cypriot media and broader political scene. It has been repeatedly accused of promoting racism and being involved in acts of violence. Guest workers have reportedly often been a target of racial abuse from employers, landlords and government employees.<ref name=":0" />
==Denmark== {{main|Racism in Denmark}} A poll from YouGov in 2019 showed that 72% rated their view on Romas as "totally negative", remarkably higher than the other polled Northern European countries,<ref name="icenews">{{cite news |title=Denmark is most intolerant country in northern Europe |url=https://yougov.co.uk/topics/politics/articles-reports/2015/06/05/european-attitudes-minorities |access-date=26 July 2023 |publisher=Yougov |date=5 June 2015}}</ref> Muslims were also viewed more negatively, with 45% having a negative view. This was also tied first with Finland. The perception of Black people and Jews, were however lower than the average of the polled countries, with 11% and 8% respectively. In 2014 it was reported that Adoptees with foreign background are often racially abused.<ref>{{cite web |title=Foreign adoptees in Denmark often racially abused |url=https://www.icenews.is/2014/12/09/foreign-adoptees-in-denmark-often-racially-abused/ |website=Icenews |date=9 December 2014 |access-date=28 August 2019}}</ref>
Young non-ethnic Danes have complained that some police officers have acted in a racist manner.<ref>[http://politiken.dk/indland/ECE472795/politi-de-unge-klager-over-racistiske-betjente/ Politi: De unge klager over racistiske betjente], by Andreas Lindquist, ''Politiken'', 18 February 2008</ref>
The term ''hyggeracisme'' ([[hygge]] + racism) is used by some to describe racist phrases/jokes, where the person saying the phrase may perceive it as being unproblematic and funny.<ref>{{Cite web |title=hyggeracisme — Den Danske Ordbog |url=https://ordnet.dk/ddo/ordbog?query=hyggeracisme |access-date=2022-06-10 |website=ordnet.dk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-06-15 |title=Hinda på 24 oplever tit hyggeracisme: 'Det er klamt, når fyrene ser min hudfarve som en fetich' |url=https://www.dr.dk/mitliv/tvaers/hinda-paa-24-oplever-tit-hyggeracisme-det-er-klamt-naar-fyrene-ser-min-hudfarve-som-en |access-date=2022-06-10 |website=DR |language=da}}</ref>
==Estonia== In the mid-2010s, NATO soldiers from the U.S. stationed in Estonia as part of [[Enhanced Forward Presence]] were subject to racist attacks by local civilians, resulting in condemnations from the Estonian Air Force's commander, [[Jaak Tarien]], and the U.S. embassy's chargé d'affaires.<ref name=Observer>{{cite web|url=https://observer.com/2016/02/estonia-wants-more-nato-troops-but-only-if-they-arent-black/|title=Estonia Wants More NATO Troops—But Only If They Aren't Black|date=22 February 2016|work=Observer|access-date=29 May 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://estonia.usembassy.gov/sp_eng110415.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20160328230440/http://estonia.usembassy.gov/sp_eng110415.html|url-status=dead|title=Speeches and Articles - Tallinn, Estonia - Embassy of the United Stat…|date=28 March 2016|archive-date=28 March 2016|website=archive.is}}</ref> Some Estonians, particularly from the [[Conservative People's Party of Estonia|Conservative People's Party]], voiced their displeasure at the condemnations.<ref name=Observer/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rubaltic.ru/article/segodnya-v-pribaltike/17112015-estoniya-rasizm/|script-title=ru:Американский дипломат осудила расизм в Эстонии|access-date=26 February 2016|work=RuBaltic|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160226124801/http://www.rubaltic.ru/article/segodnya-v-pribaltike/17112015-estoniya-rasizm/|archive-date=26 February 2016|language=Russian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://rus.err.ee/v/estonia/5158b28a-87cf-4dcc-aeab-2752f9801619/konservatory-obvinili-diplomata-ssha-vo-vmeshatelstve-v-dela-estonii|script-title=ru:Консерваторы обвинили дипломата США во вмешательстве в дела Эстонии|work=Rus - ERR|year=2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151225102922/http://rus.err.ee/v/estonia/5158b28a-87cf-4dcc-aeab-2752f9801619/konservatory-obvinili-diplomata-ssha-vo-vmeshatelstve-v-dela-estonii|access-date=25 December 2015|archive-date=25 December 2015|language=Russian}}</ref>
The [[Conservative People's Party of Estonia]] has been described by critics as [[xenophobia|xenophobic]] and racist.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://apnews.com/0e231a1618774541964fae0b226ec11e|title=Center-right party tops Estonia vote, but populists win, too|first=Jari|last=Tanner|date=3 March 2019|website=AP NEWS}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://yanatoom.ee/brusseli-paevik/brusseli-paevik-yana-toomiga-miks-tegelikult-koik-nii-ullatunud-on/|title="Brüsseli päevik Yana Toomiga": miks tegelikult kõik nii üllatunud on? - Yana Toom|access-date=10 May 2019|archive-date=27 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190327101223/http://yanatoom.ee/brusseli-paevik/brusseli-paevik-yana-toomiga-miks-tegelikult-koik-nii-ullatunud-on/|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sotsid.ee/jevgeni-ossinovski-ma-tahan-eestit-kus-iga-meie-inimene-on-vaartus-kus-iga-meie-inimene-on-oma/|title=Jevgeni Ossinovski: Ma tahan Eestit, kus iga meie inimene on väärtus, kus iga meie inimene on oma|date=15 May 2016|website=Sotsiaaldemokraadid}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kesknadal.ee/2019/01/06/raimond-kaljulaid-ekre-programm-on-ootusparaselt-utoopiline/|title=Raimond Kaljulaid: EKRE programm on ootuspäraselt utoopiline – Kesknädal|date=6 January 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://thebulwark.com/no-not-all-nationalists-are-inspired-by-trump/|title=No, Not All Nationalists Are 'Inspired By Trump'|date=10 May 2019|website=The Bulwark}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.err.ee/107416/conservative-politician-if-you-re-black-go-back|title=Conservative Politician: If You're Black, Go Back|date=29 May 2013|website=ERR}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.delfi.ee/a/82522277|title=Mart Helme vihakõne koosolekul: Tallinnas on plahvatuslikult kasvanud neegrite hulk. Kui neile vastu pead koputada, siis see on õõnespuit!|website=Delfi}}</ref>
==Finland== {{main|Racism in Finland}} Reports say that racial hate crime is a recent phenomenon, and that they are on the rise.<ref>[http://cms.horus.be/files/99935/MediaArchive/pdf/finland_en.pdf Responding to racism in Finland]. European Network Against Racism</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/news/2010/11/hate_crimes_against_foreigners_rise_2111368.html |title=Hate Crimes against Foreigners Rise | Yle Uutiset |publisher=yle.fi |access-date=29 May 2012}}</ref> The numbers of reported hate crimes in 2003 and 2004 were 522 and 558, respectively. In 2009, they had increased to over 1,000 (including non-racist hate crimes). Racial hate crimes have fluctuated from 858 (2009) to 641 (2012)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.poliisiammattikorkeakoulu.fi/poliisi/poliisioppilaitos/home.nsf/PFBD/AA662EFEA0162E5FC2257C1B0022E970?opendocument | title=Poliisin tietoon tullut viharikollisuus vähentynyt | website=poliisiammattikorkeakoulu.fi | year=2013 | access-date=3 September 2014 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903171135/http://www.poliisiammattikorkeakoulu.fi/poliisi/poliisioppilaitos/home.nsf/PFBD/AA662EFEA0162E5FC2257C1B0022E970?opendocument | archive-date=3 September 2014 | url-status=dead }}</ref> and the typical suspect have been a Finnish-born young man. However, over 60% of the targets were reported to have been Finland-born, although those with foreign-born parents were counted as well. The most targeted immigrants in 2004 were reported to be of [[Somali people|Somali]], [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]], [[Russians|Russian]], [[Iraqi people|Iraqi]] and [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] origin. One-third of the hate crimes were reportedly aimed at the [[Finnish Kale|Kale]], and only one in six were members of the native population.
In European Social Surveys since 2002, Finns have proved to be least racist just after Swedes. Earlier Finnish scientific data reveals that attitudes had been improving continuously for a long time.<ref>[http://www.fsd.uta.fi/lehti/fi/28/tietoarkisto09.pdf Yhteiskuntatieteellinen tietoarkisto | www.fsd.uta.fi | 2009].</ref> Professor of Social Policy and responsible of Finnish ESS, Heikki Ervasti, denies a common thought of increased negative attitudes against immigrants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tylkkari.fi/ilmiot/kyokkipuheesta-poliittiseksi-voimaksi |title= Kyökkipuheesta poliittiseksi voimaksi | publisher=tylkkari.fi |year= 2012}}</ref>
A poll made in late 2011 revealed that the majority of the Finns viewed Finland as a racist country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Poll+Majority+of+Finns+see+Finland+as+racist+country/1135269860316 |title=Helsingin Sanomat International Edition – Home |work=Helsingin Sanomat |access-date=29 May 2012}}</ref> Two thirds considered the country to be fairly racist, 12% recognised a moderate amount of racism, and 2% admitted to be very racist; 35% agreed partly or wholly to the statement "Islam is a threat to Western values and democracy", and 29% agreed more or less to that "people belonging to certain races simply are not suited to live in a modern society". One in five thought "it needs to be recognised as a fact that some nations are more intelligent than others", and 11% agreed partly or completely to "people whose appearance and culture differ much from those of the Finns are unpredictable and frightening".
==France== {{main|Racism in France}} In 1998, the Council of Europe's European Commission Against Racism and Intolerance (ECRI) made a report stating concern about racist activities in France and accused the French authorities of not doing enough to combat this. The report and other groups have expressed concern about organizations such as [[Front National (France)]]. In a recent [[Pew Research Center|Pew Survey]], 47% of the French deem immigration from [[Central and Eastern Europe]] (mainly from [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Hungary]], [[Serbia]] and [[Romania]], including [[Slavs|Slavic]] and [[Romani people]]) to be a very bad thing. Likewise, the majority of French respondents revealed negative views on the immigration of [[Muslims]] from [[Africa]] and the [[Middle East]]. A small minority showed signs of anti-Semitism. Roughly 11% had an unfavorable view of Jews<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pewglobal.org/reports/display.php?PageID=795 |title=Pew Global Attitudes Project: Summary of Findings: A Year After Iraq War |access-date=16 December 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216042207/http://pewglobal.org/reports/display.php?PageID=795 |archive-date=16 December 2009 }} (16 March 2004)</ref> and 8% felt that US policy was most influenced by the Jews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pewglobal.org/reports/display.php?PageID=803 |title=Pew Global Attitudes Project: III: Opinions of U.S. Policies: U.S. Image Up Slightly, But Still Negative |access-date=12 February 2008 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091211125844/http://pewglobal.org/reports/display.php?PageID=803 |archive-date=11 December 2009 }}</ref>
==Germany== {{main|Racism in Germany}} {{Update|section|reason=the section does not mention modern cases post-[[WWII]]|date=May 2021}} The period after Germany lost [[World War I]] led to an increased use of [[Antisemitism|anti-Semitism]] and other forms of [[racism]] in political discourse, for example among the right-wing [[Freikorps]], emotions that finally culminated in the ascent to power of [[Adolf Hitler]] and the [[Nazi Party]] in 1933. The [[Nazi racial policy]] and the [[Nuremberg Laws|Nuremberg Race Laws]] against Jews and other non-[[Aryan race|Aryans]] represented the most explicit racist policies in Europe in the twentieth century. These laws deprived all Jews including even half-Jews and quarter-Jews as well as other non-Aryans from German citizenship. Jews' official title became "subject of the state". The Nuremberg Race Laws forbade racially mixed sexual relations and marriage between Aryans and at first Jews but was later extended to "Gypsies, Negroes or their bastard offspring".<ref name="Burleigh1991">{{cite book | author = Michael Burleigh | title = The Racial State: Germany 1933-1945 | url = https://archive.org/details/racialstate00mich | url-access = registration | date = 7 November 1991 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 978-0-521-39802-2 | page = [https://archive.org/details/racialstate00mich/page/49 49]}}</ref> Such interracial relations became a criminal and punishable offence under the race laws known as "racial pollution" [[Rassenschande]].<ref name="Burleigh1991" /><ref>{{cite book | author = S. H. Milton | chapter = "Gypsies" as social outsiders in Nazi Germany| title = Social Outsiders in Nazi Germany | editor = Robert Gellately and Nathan Stoltzfus | year = 2001 | publisher = Princeton University Press | isbn = 9780691086842 | pages = 216, 231}}</ref> Racism in Nazi Germany was also influenced by [[Martin Luther]]'s antisemitism.<ref name="Romocea 2011 p. 60">{{cite book | last=Romocea | first=C. | title=Church and State: Religious Nationalism and State Identification in Post-Communist Romania | publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing | year=2011 | isbn=978-1-4411-3747-0 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2eTWl65GB1gC&pg=PA60 | access-date=2023-03-05 | page=60}}</ref>
==Greece== [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]] emerged as a fringe movement when it was founded in the early 1980s and since then, it has evolved into a [[Far-right politics|far-right]] group within [[Greece]]. Members of Golden Dawn have been accused of carrying out acts of violence as well as [[hate crimes]] against [[Immigration|immigrants]], political opponents, [[Homosexuality|homosexuals]] and ethnic minorities.<ref>{{Citation |title=How Greece Elected Nazis {{!}} Decade of Hate |date=June 11, 2021 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=onhIFlqqJi0 |publisher=[[Vice (magazine)|VICE]] |language=en}}</ref> In late 2020, the party's leader, Nikolaos Michaloliakos, and six other prominent members and former MPs, were charged with running a criminal organization<ref>{{Cite web|last=Samaras|first=Georgios|title=The end of Golden Dawn: has Greece shown us how to deal with neo-Nazis?|url=http://theconversation.com/the-end-of-golden-dawn-has-greece-shown-us-how-to-deal-with-neo-nazis-150239|access-date=27 January 2021|website=The Conversation|language=en}}</ref> and guilty verdicts on charges of murder, attempted murder, and violent attacks on immigrants and left-wing political opponents were delivered<ref>{{Cite web |title=Greece Golden Dawn: Neo-Nazi leaders guilty of running crime gang |work=BBC News |date=7 October 2020 |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-54433396 |access-date=7 October 2020}}</ref> and they were sent to prison.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ekathimerini.com/news/258402/golden-dawn-leaders-go-to-jail/|title=Golden Dawn leaders go to jail|work=Kathimerini|date=23 October 2020|access-date=16 May 2021}}</ref>
The Athens-based Racist Violence Recording Network has documented attacks by organised groups across the country against those perceived to be migrants or Muslims.<ref>{{Citation |title=World Report 2021: Greece |date=2021-01-13 |url=https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2021/country-chapters/greece |work=[[Human Rights Watch]] |language=en |access-date=2022-07-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=2018-03-28 |title=Racist violence creeping up in Greece, report finds |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-greece-racism-idUSKBN1H41VF |access-date=2022-07-07}}</ref>
==Hungary== An [[European Union|EU]] report found that legal policies that should protect people from racism and [[xenophobia]] were "not implemented effectively", and it also found that Hungarian public officials denied the fact that racism and discrimination were a problem in their country, despite evidence to the contrary. It noted that such factors contributed to the increase in extremist ideologies in Hungarian politics and media.<ref name="FRA">{{cite news |url=http://fra.europa.eu/sites/default/files/fra-2013-thematic-situation-report-3_en_1.pdf |title=Racism, discrimination, intolerance and extremism: learning from experiences in Greece and Hungary |publisher=European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA) |date=December 2013 |access-date=22 February 2014}}</ref> The Council of Europe has also criticized Hungary in a new report, condemning xenophobia and violence against migrants and minorities.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dw.com/en/eu-report-finds-rampant-racism-xenophobia-in-hungary/a-18505689 |title=EU Report in Deutsche Welle}}</ref>
2013 [[Fundamental Rights Agency|FRA]] online survey shows a middle to high level of [[Antisemitism in contemporary Hungary|anti-Semitism in Hungary]], compared to other European countries.<ref name="FRA"/> The banned [[Hungarian Guard]] and some [[Jobbik]] politicians are sometimes described as xenophobic and racist.<ref name="FRA"/>
As in other European countries, [[Romani people in Hungary]] faced disadvantages, including unequal treatment, discrimination, segregation and harassment. Negative stereotypes are often linked to the high level of unemployment among Romani people and their reliance on state benefits.<ref name="FRA"/> In 2008 and 2009 nine attacks took place against Romani in Hungary, resulting in six deaths and multiple injuries. According to the Hungarian curia (supreme court), these murders were motivated by [[Antiziganism|anti-Romani sentiment]] and sentenced the perpetrators to [[life imprisonment]].<ref name="FRA"/>
==Ireland==
Historically, the most serious racial problems in Ireland stemmed from the colonization of the country by the British, and the racist attitude of the colonists to the native Irish. The English considered themselves to be a distinct race from the Irish, who were classified as '[[Melanochroi]]', or 'half black' by [[Thomas Huxley]].{{citation needed|date=February 2019}} Depictions of the Irish in the popular British press throughout the centuries of British colonisation were noted for their portrayal of the Irish as subhuman.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.historyireland.com/18th-19th-century-history/punch-and-the-great-famine-by-peter-gray/|title=Punch and the Great Famine|last=Gray|first=Peter|publisher=History Ireland|date=Summer 1993|access-date=26 July 2021}}</ref> Laws suppressing Irish culture and enfranchisement, outlawing the use of the [[Irish language]], education, and the practice of the Roman Catholicism were enforced during various periods from the 14th century onward (see [[Statutes of Kilkenny]] and [[Penal Laws (Ireland)]]).
===20th century=== During the second world war, although [[Irish neutrality during World War II|Ireland was officially neutral]], [[Taoiseach]] [[Éamon de Valera]] was accused of sympathizing with and supporting the [[Nazi regime]] of [[Adolf Hitler]] in Germany. Following the death of Hitler in 1945, de Valera was one of many who signed a book of condolence and offered sympathies to the German ambassador at the Embassy in [[Dublin]].<ref>''An Irish Statesman and Revolutionary'' by Elizabeth Keane ({{ISBN|978-1845111250}}), page 106</ref> This led to the belief among [[Allies of World War II|Allied leaders]] such as [[Winston Churchill|Churchill]] that de Valera and the Irish in general were supportive of the Nazi regime.<ref>{{cite web|title=Irish Public Service Broadcasting – 1940s: De Valera and Broadcasting|work=History of RTÉ|publisher=Raidió Teilifís Éireann|url=http://www.rte.ie/laweb/brc/brc_1940s_a.html|access-date=30 October 2008}}</ref> The substantial influx of Nazi war criminals to Ireland following the war and their acceptance into society both officially by the Government of Ireland and by the general public also lead to claims Ireland was tolerant if not supportive of the Nazi regime.<ref>"Hidden History: Ireland's Nazis", broadcast by RTÉ - January 2007</ref> However, it must also be borne in mind that Germany had supplied guns to the Irish War of Independence 20 years earlier, and so Irish sympathies to the Germans rather than their long-standing British oppressors can easily be understood in this way, rather than due to anti-semitism. (Main article: [[History of the Jews in Ireland]]).
In mid-twentieth century Ireland there was traditionally very little [[immigration]] in general to the Republic of Ireland, and hence little racial diversity, though in recent decades growing prosperity in the country (see: [[Celtic Tiger]]) attracted increasing numbers of [[immigrants]], mainly from [[Central and Eastern Europe]] (primarily [[Poland]]), [[China]] and [[Sub-Saharan Africa]]. Also, the absence of colonialist baggage has meant that foreign people are not drawn to Ireland by "[[mother country]]" factors that have affected other European countries. Descendants of [[Irish people]] who emigrated in the past also started moving to the country. Most immigrants have settled in [[Dublin]] and the other cities. Though these developments have been somewhat tolerated by most, there has been a steady rise in racist attitudes among some sections of society. A 2001 survey found that 51% of Irish people surveyed considered the country inherently racist<ref>Liam Collins. [http://www.independent.ie/national-news/ireland-is-a-country-of-racists--at-least-the-irish-think-thats-true-508512.html Ireland is a country of racists – at least the Irish think that's true – National News]. Independent.ie (27 May 2001). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref> and 60% of those in the 25 to 34 age group considered "racism" to be an Irish trait. In 2005, Minister of State for Overseas Development, Conor Lenihan famously advised Socialist politician Joe Higgins to "stick with the kebabs" – referring to his campaigning on behalf of [[Turkey|Turkish]] contract workers who had been paid less than the statutory minimum wage. The Minister later retracted his remarks and apologized.<ref>Michael O’Farrell. [https://web.archive.org/web/20120602064451/http://www.irishexaminer.com/archives/2005/0519/ireland/lenihan-under-pressure-to-apologise-for-kebab-gaffe-626825454.html Lenihan under pressure to apologise for ‘kebab’ gaffe]. The Irish Examiner (19 May 2005)</ref> A 2008 EU-MIDIS survey of attitudes to minorities in the 27 EU States found that Ireland had the most racist attitudes to Afro-Europeans in the entire EU.<ref>Jim Cusack. [http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/ireland-of-the-welcomes-is-a-myth-2133538.html Ireland of the welcomes is a myth – Analysis, Opinion]. Independent.ie (11 April 2010). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref>

In 2000, a white man was stabbed and seriously injured when defending his [[Jamaica]]n-born wife from racist abuse by a group of adult men.<ref>Tim Healy. Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref> In 2002, a [[Chinese people|Chinese]] man Zhao Liu Tao (29) was murdered in Dublin in what was described as the Republic of Ireland's first racially motivated murder.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/1813880.stm Murder sparks Irish racism fears], [[BBC News]] (11 February 2002)</ref> Later that year Leong Ly Min, a [[Vietnamese people|Vietnamese]] man who had lived in Dublin since 1979,<ref>[http://republican-news.org/archive/2002/August29/29anti.html Rally against racist attacks] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080225105217/http://republican-news.org/archive/2002/August29/29anti.html |date=25 February 2008 }}, [[Republican News]] (29 August 2002)</ref> was mortally wounded by two assailants who had been racially abusing him.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/ireland/article7094192.ece Death of a dream as racism rears its head in Ireland], [[The Times]] (11 April 2010)</ref> In February 2008, two [[Polish people|Polish]] mechanics, Paweł Kalita (29) and Mariusz Szwajkos (27) were attacked by a group of Dublin youths and died outside their home after each being stabbed in the head with a screwdriver.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Man guilty of murdering Polish men |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/man-guilty-of-murdering-polish-men-1.857453 |access-date=2022-12-12 |website=The Irish Times |language=en}}</ref> In 2010, 15-year-old schoolboy [[Toyosi Shittabey]], born in [[Nigeria]] but brought up in Dublin, was killed. In contrast, the US scored highest among all the countries surveyed, being more welcoming to people of different races and ethnic groups than even the highest-scoring European nation, the UK.<ref name=PewResearchCenter>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/files/2016/07/FT_16.07.11_EU-USdiversity_ideology.png|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171126194203/http://www.pewresearch.org/files/2016/07/FT_16.07.11_EU-USdiversity_ideology.png|url-status=dead|archive-date=26 November 2017|title=Ideological right less likely than left to say diversity makes the country better|access-date=26 November 2017|author=Pew Research Center|work=Global Attitudes Survey|publisher=Pew Research Center|date=March 2016}}</ref>
Researchers from the [[University of Amsterdam]] and [[Utrecht University]] conducted between 2016 and 2018 a study where they sent 4,200 job application letters to companies. The fictional applicants were between 23 and 25 years old, with four years of work experience, and applied for real vacancies. All the applicants had a Dutch nationality, but the names and mother tongue of the applicants were adjusted. The conclusion was that Dutch people had the most chances of being invited for a job interview. The candidates with a Western immigrant background had 20% less chance of being invited. And the candidates who had a non-Western immigrant background faced the biggest discrimination with 40% of the applicants not being invited to a job interview. Especially applicants with a Turkish, Moroccan or Antillean background were discriminated against. A side note from the study was that during economic downturns, there was an increased amount of discrimination. For applicants who were discriminated against, an improved CV didn't improve their chances of being invited.<ref>{{cite web | work= Algemeen Dagblad|location= The Netherlands | author= Marloe van der Schrier | url= https://www.ad.nl/ad-werkt/nog-volop-discriminatie-bij-sollicitaties-inhoud-cv-maakt-nauwelijks-uit~a7567cc9/ |title= Nog volop discriminatie bij sollicitaties: inhoud cv maakt nauwelijks uit (English: Still plenty of discrimination in job applications: content of CV hardly makes any difference) |access-date= 23 November 2019}}</ref>

==Russia== {{main|Racism in Russia}} {{further|History of the Jews in the Soviet Union|History of the Jews in Russia}} The term "[[pogrom]]" became commonly used in English after a large-scale wave of anti-Jewish riots swept through south-western [[Russian Empire|Czarist Russia]] in 1881–1884. A much bloodier wave of pogroms broke out in 1903–1906, leaving an estimated 2,000 Jews dead. By the beginning of the 20th century, most European Jews lived in the so-called [[Pale of Settlement]], the Western frontier of the [[Russian Empire]] consisting generally of the modern-day countries of Poland, Lithuania, Belarus and neighboring regions. Many pogroms accompanied the [[Russian Revolution|Revolution of 1917]] and the ensuing [[Russian Civil War]], an estimated 70,000 to 250,000 civilian Jews were killed in the atrocities throughout the former [[Russian Empire]]; the number of Jewish orphans exceeded 300,000.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|url=http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-215022/anti-Semitism|title=anti-Semitism|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica|access-date=17 June 2015}}</ref><ref>Hilary L Rubinstein, Daniel C Cohn-Sherbok, Abraham J Edelheit, William D Rubinstein, ''The Jews in the Modern World'', Oxford University Press, 2002.</ref>
In the 2000s, [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]] groups inside [[Russia]] had risen to include as many as tens of thousands of people.<ref>{{cite news| title=A gathering storm of Russian thugs | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/08/14/MNGUSE7N2D1.DTL | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | first=Anna | last=Badkhen | date=14 August 2005}}</ref> Racism against both the Russian citizens ([[peoples of the Caucasus]], [[indigenous peoples of Siberia|indigenous peoples of Siberia and Russian Far East]], etc.) and non-Russian citizens of African, Central Asian, East Asian (Vietnamese, Chinese, etc.) and European (Irish, etc.) heritage is a significant problem.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=726|title=Racist Violence, Rhetoric Plague Russia|access-date=17 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091018174645/http://www.splcenter.org/intel/intelreport/article.jsp?aid=726|archive-date=18 October 2009|url-status=dead}}</ref>
Since 2008, the number of [[hate crime]]s in [[Russia]] declined significantly.<ref>{{cite web|author=10 March 2010 |url=http://www.sova-center.ru/en/xenophobia/reports-analyses/2010/03/d18151/ |title=Galina Kozhevnikova. Under the Sign of Political Terror. Radical Nationalism and Efforts to Counteract It in 2009 |publisher=Sova-center.ru }}</ref> {{blockquote|The main outcome of 2009 was a clear reduction in the number of victims of racist and neo-Nazi motivated violence for the first time in six years of observation conducted by SOVA Center. To some extent, credit should go to the law enforcement agencies who suppressed the largest and most aggressive ultra-right groups in the Moscow region in the second half of 2008 and in 2009. However, despite all efforts, xenophobic violence remains alarming in its scope and extends over most of the Russian regions, affecting hundreds of people.|Galina Kozhevnikova|[[SOVA Center]]}}
The [[Russian Orthodox Church]] "believes it is vital for Russia to pursue anti-extremist campaign and develop a sustainable strategy." As a result, it has called for immigrants to be given jobs and the opportunity to learn more about [[Russian culture]]. In addition, it has called for skinheads to refocus their mission to legally preventing crime and immoral behavior.<ref>{{cite web|title=Russian Church calls to give legal jobs to illegal immigrants and let skinheads legally fight Crime|url=http://theorthodoxchurch.info/blog/news/2011/08/russian-church-calls-to-give-legal-jobs-to-illegal-immigrants-and-let-skinheads-legally-fight-crime/|publisher=OCP Media Network|access-date=22 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130702033810/http://theorthodoxchurch.info/blog/news/2011/08/russian-church-calls-to-give-legal-jobs-to-illegal-immigrants-and-let-skinheads-legally-fight-crime/|archive-date=2 July 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref>
==Slovenia== [[Romani people]] have become the main target of Slovenian racists in the 21st century as the population is otherwise extremely homogeneous.<ref>[http://www.humaniteinenglish.com/article441.html Slovenia: Chasing out the Roma]. Humaniteinenglish.com (5 December 2006). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref>
==Spain== {{main|Racism in Spain}} [[Romani people in Spain|Gitanos]] are viewed with less sympathy than other groups.<ref name="Gitanos">[http://www.gitanos.org/areas/igualdad_de_trato_y_no_discriminacion/noticias/26701.html Nuevas encuestas del CIS sitúan a los gitanos como el grupo social más rechazado, mientras que un estudio sociológico refleja los importantes avances de esta comunidad], 2007.</ref>
Racist abuse aimed at black footballers has been reported at [[Spanish football league]] matches in recent years. This has led to protests and [[UEFA]] fines against clubs whose supporters continue the abuse. Several players in the Spanish league including Barcelona striker [[Samuel Eto'o]] and Espanyol goalkeeper [[Carlos Kameni]] have suffered and spoken out against the abuse. In 2006, Real Zaragoza player [[Ewerthon]] stated: "the Spanish Federation have to start taking proper measures and we as Afro-European players also have to act."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4751876.stm Eto'o makes anti-racism protest] BBC News</ref>
==Sweden== {{main|Racism in Sweden}}
In 1922 Sweden established the [[Statens institut för rasbiologi]], or state institute for race biology.<ref>[[:sv:Rasbiologi|race-biology institute]]</ref> The institute recommended the sterilization by force of the mentally ill, physically disabled, homosexuals and ethnic minorities, which was allowed by Swedish law until 1975.<ref>[[:sv:Sterilisering (ingrepp)|sterilization]]</ref>
According to the 2005 report ''Racism and Xenophobia in Sweden'' by the Board of Integration, Muslims are exposed to the most religious harassment in Sweden. Almost 40% of the interviewed said they had witnessed verbal abuse directed at Muslims.<ref>25 October 2005 [http://www.thelocal.se/article.php?ID=2363&date=20051025 The Local: Muslims face most racism in Sweden] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118040227/http://www.thelocal.se/article.php?ID=2363&date=20051025|date=18 January 2008}}. ''[[The Local]]''. Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref> [[European Network Against Racism]] in Sweden claims that in today's Sweden there exists a clear ethnic hierarchy when ethnic Swedes are at the top and non-European immigrants are at the bottom.<ref>[http://cms.horus.be/files/99935/MediaArchive/pdf/Sweden_EN.pdf Responding to racism in Sweden] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160607081246/http://cms.horus.be/files/99935/MediaArchive/pdf/Sweden_EN.pdf |date=7 June 2016 }}. (PDF). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref>
In 1999, Neo-Nazis in Malexander murdered two policemen during a robbery to obtain funds for a fascist organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.expressen.se/nyheter/inloggad/nazister-ranare-och-polismordare---sa-lever-de-i-dag/|title=Nazister, rånare och polismördare - så lever de i dag - Inloggad - Expressen|website=Expressen}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wwwc.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/9910/15/polismord2.html|title=Aftonbladet nyheter: Polismorden i Malexander|website=Aftonbladet}}</ref><ref name=bakgrund>{{cite news|title=Bakgrund: Polismorden i Malexander |first=P. O. |last=Lindström |url=http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/bakgrund-polismorden-i-malexander_156474.svd |newspaper=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |language=Swedish |date=28 July 2004 |access-date=23 March 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007234501/http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/bakgrund-polismorden-i-malexander_156474.svd |archive-date=7 October 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Fakta: Malexandermorden |trans-title=Fact: Malexander murders |first=Anna |last=Mattsson |url=http://www.expressen.se/nyheter/fakta-malexandermorden/ |newspaper=[[Expressen]] |language=Swedish |date=28 May 2007 |access-date=23 March 2012}}</ref>
[[Sveriges Radio]] reported that the punishments for driving under the influence of alcohol tended to be harsher for immigrants than for Swedes; while over 50% of immigrants were sent to jail for driving under the effect of alcohol, only less than 30% of ethnic Swedes were sent to jail with the same level of alcohol found in blood.<ref>[http://www.sr.se/cgi-bin/ekot/artikel.asp?Artikel=403326 Harder punishments to immigrants] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050413053607/http://www.sr.se/cgi-bin/ekot/artikel.asp?artikel=403326 |date=13 April 2005 }}. Sr.se (22 April 2004). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref> There has been evidence that the Swedish police used "Neger Niggersson" as a nickname for a criminal in a police training; this was published in Swedish media.<ref>[http://www.thelocal.se/17424/20090207/ Racist stereotypes used in police training] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090514072116/http://www.thelocal.se/17424/20090207 |date=14 May 2009 }}. Thelocal.se (20 May 2012). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref> Lately however, many incidents of racial attitudes and discrimination of the Swedish police have led for the first time to the control of racial attitudes of police students under police education<ref>{{in lang|sv}} [http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/artikel_3516139.svd Control of police attitudes]. Svd.se (14 September 2009). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref> A recent research done by the Swedish Confederation for Professional Employees (TCO) found that people with foreign background have much lower chances of finding a job that is appropriate for their education, even when they have grown up in Sweden and got their education in Swedish institutes.<ref>[http://www.tco.se/Templates/Page2____417.aspx?DataID=8753 Academic immigrants discriminates in labour market] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820213610/http://www.tco.se/Templates/Page2____417.aspx?DataID=8753 |date=20 August 2010 }}. Tco.se (11 March 2009). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref>
In 2007, there were a total of 3,536 hate crimes (defined as crimes with an ethnic or religious motive) reported to the police, including 118 cases of anti-Semitic agitation.<ref>[http://fra.europa.eu/fraWebsite/attachments/Antisemitism_Update_2009.pdf Fundamental Rights Agency report (pdf)]. (PDF). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref> Racism in Sweden is reported to appear within Swedish health-care services as well. A nurse at a Stockholm suburb hospital lost his job after complaining on racial attitudes of the hospital staff to patients with immigrant background. Staff was cited saying "[[Go back where you came from|go back]] to Arabia", "the patient is screaming because it's in his culture."<ref>[http://www.dn.se/sthlm/skoterska-slog-larm-forlorar-jobbet-1.960497 Nurse speaks out about racism] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926075530/http://www.dn.se/sthlm/skoterska-slog-larm-forlorar-jobbet-1.960497 |date=26 September 2009 }}. Dn.se (24 September 2009). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref>
Swedish social services have reported on racism in Swedish hospitals as well.<ref>[http://www.dn.se/sthlm/skoterska-slog-larm-forlorar-jobbet-1.960497 Social services identify racism in Swedish hospitals] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926075530/http://www.dn.se/sthlm/skoterska-slog-larm-forlorar-jobbet-1.960497 |date=26 September 2009 }}. Dn.se (24 September 2009). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref> A study of statistics Sweden (SCB) reveals that segregation is widespread for Swedish immigrants when there are large differences in the fields of education, housing, employment and politics between immigrants and ethnic Swedes.<ref>[http://www.thelocal.se/16452/20081218/ Segregation 'widespread' for Swedish immigrants] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090529065650/http://www.thelocal.se/16452/20081218/ |date=29 May 2009 }}. Thelocal.se (20 May 2012). Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref> Sweden has been criticized by the UN human rights council for an increasing number of hate crimes which seldom resulted in criminal charges, when more hate crimes are Islamophobic, and homophobic, with an increasing amount of racist propaganda appearing on the internet and in Sweden's schools, for failing to provide adequate health care and education to immigrants, asylum seekers and undocumented migrants and the ongoing discrimination of the Roma and Sami minorities in Sweden.<ref>[http://www.thelocal.se/23150/20091109/ Sweden slammed for UN rights failures] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091111120803/http://www.thelocal.se/23150/20091109/|date=11 November 2009}}. [[The Local]]. Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref>
A study was conducted in 2011 about the Swedes attitudes to mixed marriages. The conclusion was that the views in general were favorable, but that there was a strong hierarchy based on which groups to live with. Swedes primarily preferred relationships with Scandinavians, Western Europeans and Southern Europeans, and then Eastern Europeans, Central Europeans and Latin Americans. At the bottom were South and East Asians, Africans, and Middle Eastern people. Older individuals and women, as well as people with less education and people who were brought up outside of [[Malmö]] (the most multicultural city of Sweden), were generally more prone to having negative attitudes. Most were able to accept family members and friends living in mixed relationships, even if they did not want to do it themselves.<ref>{{cite web|author=Text: Johanna Svensson |url=http://www.mah.se/english/News/News-2011/-Love-aint-got-no-color--Attitude-toward-interracial-marriage/ |title=Love ain't got no color? – Attitude toward interracial marriage – Malmö University |publisher=Mah.se |date=27 September 2011 |access-date=29 May 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20120905111204/http://www.mah.se/english/News/News-2011/-Love-aint-got-no-color--Attitude-toward-interracial-marriage/ |archive-date=5 September 2012 }}</ref>
Swedish national television (SVT) has reported on a new research done in Sweden which identifies that job seekers with a Swedish name have 50% higher chances to be called for an interview than job seekers with middle-eastern names. The research enlightens that there is not much difference between foreign-born job seekers and job seekers born in Sweden if both don't have a Swedish name; this indicates that ethnic discrimination is the main cause of the variations.<ref>[http://svt.se/2.22620/1.1795381/invandrare_kallas_inte_till_intervju?lid=senasteNytt_275216&lpos=rubrik_1795381 Immigrants are not called for job interviews] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110217015211/http://svt.se/2.22620/1.1795381/invandrare_kallas_inte_till_intervju?lid=senasteNytt_275216&lpos=rubrik_1795381 |date=17 February 2011 }}. Svt.se. Retrieved 2 June 2012.</ref>

In 2015, [[Trollhättan school stabbing|a mass stabbing]] occurred when a Swedish man motivated by opposition to immigration attacked four people at a school in Trollhättan with a sword, killing three, before committing [[suicide by cop]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Police: Trollhättan school attacker "wanted to die" - Radio Sweden|url=https://sverigesradio.se/artikel/6385516|access-date=9 February 2021|website=sverigesradio.se|language=en}}</ref>
==Switzerland== {{see also|Immigration to Switzerland#Racism|l1=Racism in Switzerland}} [[Switzerland|The Swiss Confederation]] or ''Confederatio Helvetica'' is a country composed of four subcultural groups: German-speaking (63.7%), French-speaking (20.4%), Italian-speaking (6.5%) and [[Romansh language|Romansh]]-speaking (0.5%).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bfs.admin.ch/bfs/portal/en/index/themen/bevoelkerung/sprachen__religionen/blank/kennzahlen0/sprachen.html |title=Languages |access-date=12 February 2008 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819110032/http://www.bfs.admin.ch/bfs/portal/en/index/themen/bevoelkerung/sprachen__religionen/blank/kennzahlen0/sprachen.html |archive-date=19 August 2006 }}. Swiss Federal Population Census 2000</ref>
Swiss "Confederation Commission Against Racism" which is part of the Swiss "Federal Department of Home Affairs"[http://www.edi.admin.ch/] published a 2004 report, ''Black People in Switzerland'': ''A Life between [[Racial integration|Integration]] and [[Discrimination]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edi.admin.ch/ekr/dokumentation/shop/00019/00142/index.html?lang=de |title=Schwarze Menschen in der Schweiz. Ein Leben zwischen Integration und Diskriminierung |access-date=12 February 2008 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050311063519/http://www.edi.admin.ch/ekr/dokumentation/shop/00019/00142/index.html?lang=de |archive-date=11 March 2005 }}. edi.admin.ch (2004)</ref> (published in German, French, and Italian only). According to this report, discrimination based on skin colour in Switzerland is not exceptional, and affects immigrants decades after their immigration.
[[Swiss People's Party]] claims that Swiss communities have a [[democracy|democratic]] right to decide who can or cannot be Swiss. In addition, the report said "Official statements and political campaigns that present immigrants from the EU in a favourable light and immigrants from elsewhere in a bad light must stop", according to the Swiss Federal Statistics Office in 2006, 85.5% of the foreign residents in Switzerland are European.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bfs.admin.ch/bfs/portal/fr/index/themen/01/07/blank/data/01.html |title=Statistique suisse – Population étrangère – Aperçu général |publisher=Bfs.admin.ch |date=3 May 2012 |access-date=29 May 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608021414/http://www.bfs.admin.ch/bfs/portal/fr/index/themen/01/07/blank/data/01.html |archive-date=8 June 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The [[United Nations]] special rapporteur on racism, [[Doudou Diène]], has observed that Switzerland suffers from racism, [[discrimination]] and [[xenophobia]]. The UN envoy explained that although the Swiss authorities recognised the existence of [[racism]] and xenophobia, they did not view the problem as being serious. Diène pointed out that representatives of minority communities said they experienced serious racism and discrimination, notably for access to public services (e.g. health care), employment and lodging.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/front/UN_envoy_calls_racism_in_Switzerland_a_reality.html?siteSect=105&sid=6382785&cKey=1137401626000&ty=st |title=UN envoy calls racism in Switzerland a reality- swissinfo |publisher=Swissinfo.ch |date=14 January 2006 |access-date=29 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6980766.stm | work=BBC News | first=Imogen | last=Foulkes | title=Swiss row over black sheep poster | date=6 September 2007}}</ref>
The [[2009 Swiss minaret referendum]] banned the construction of new minarets—towers traditionally attached to mosques—by a 57 to 43 popular vote of the country. In the [[2021 Swiss referendums]], the electorate banned the wearing of a full face covering, which some Orthodox Muslim women wear.
